intro: Acrocephalus villosus, commonly known as the hairy reed warbler, is a grass-like plant native to wetland habitats. It belongs to the Poaceae family and is characterized by its dense, tufted growth and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in marshy areas and along the edges of ponds, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its flowering period occurs in late summer, producing small, spike-like inflorescences. Acrocephalus villosus plays an important role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
